awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: High-Performance Biocatalytic Membranes with Self-Contained Radical Polymer Mediators for Water Reclamation and Reuse
awd_abstract_narration:
Access to clean water is among the greatest engineering challenges of the 21st century. Efficient use of existing freshwater resources is a primary strategy to address this challenge. However, current societal needs cannot be met without additional water from sources like brackish water and wastewater. Successful reclamation and reuse of these water sources depends on the development of technologies to ensure these waters are fit for use. This project addresses this need using natural enzymes to degrade toxic contaminants present in water. These highly-efficient biological catalysts will be formulated into biocatalytic membranes using recent advances in the fields of polymer chemistry and additive manufacturing. Biocatalytic inks that contain enzymes and other tailor-made functional components will be deposited onto nanoporous membrane supports in a modular fashion. The modular design can be customized for specific needs by changing the target enzymes and/or polymer mediators. Successful development of this technology will help address the critical challenges of the Nation to ensure the supply of safe, clean, and sustainable water resources. Broader impacts for society will result from this project by training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers to address the challenge of supplying water to the Nation.

Although efficient use of existing freshwater resources is a primary strategy to supply the Nation's water in the face of increasing demand, current societal needs cannot be met without additional water from sources like brackish water and wastewater. Successful reclamation and reuse of these water sources depends on the development of technologies to ensure these waters are fit for use. Enzyme biocatalysis is a promising platform to address this need. Such platforms require small molecular weight redox-active mediators to facilitate the enzymatic degradation of recalcitrant micropollutants. Although these small molecules provide clear benefits, they are costly and can leach from processes necessitating frequent replenishment. Therefore, it is critical to eliminate mediator washout to make this water treatment technology feasible. The overall goal of this project is to generate the scientific knowledge that enables the design and fabrication of high-performance biocatalytic membranes. This will be done by identifying control factors in the design of radical polymer-based macromolecular mediators and elucidating the processing-structure-property relationships that govern their co-deposition with enzymes on nanoporous supports. The specific research tasks to achieve this goal are to: 1) identify macromolecular mediator designs that promote the efficient degradation of micropollutants while preventing mediator washout; 2) elucidate the processing-structure-property relationships for biocatalytic membranes to correlate membrane support architecture with the biocatalytic and transport properties; and 3) evaluate biocatalytic membrane performance over the course of multiple recover and reuse cycles to inform membrane design for field-relevant applications. Successful completion of this research will address gaps in our knowledge on biocatalytic membrane design and manufacture. This knowledge will have broad impact in the fields of additive manufacturing as well as water treatment. The Nation will further benefit by the training of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers with the expertise necessary to advance the water technology landscape of the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Water scarcity and pollution are among the greatest challenges of the 21st century. While the improved use of existing freshwater sources can assist in meeting the growing demand for clean water, these resources are already stressed and cannot be stretched to meet the demands of society. Therefore, the continued development of technologies to reclaim water from non-traditional sources, such as seawater and wastewater, is of the utmost importance. In particular, the removal of chemicals that are harmful to the environment and human health is a critical need in the development of water reclamation technologies. Unfortunately, state-of-the-art treatment technologies are energy-intensive, chemically-intensive, and/or generate unwanted by-products. Conversely, enzymes, which are biological catalysts that can degrade toxic compounds to benign products, are a promising platform for the development of water reclamation processes. Notably, biocatalytic processes have been demonstrated for applications where efficient synthetic methods have yet to be developed. Moreover, enzyme biocatalysis: (i) demonstrates high catalytic efficiency, (ii) generates no toxic byproducts, and (iii) has low energy requirements. While enzyme biocatalysis holds great promise as a “green chemistry” alternative for beneficial transformations, using free enzymes in solution for contaminant removal is not suitable or economical due to the low stability, non-reusability, and the high costs associated with a single use. Additionally, the presence of redox mediators is often required to enable the oxidation of recalcitrant compounds. The high cost and toxicity of these small molecule mediators further hamper the sustainability of enzyme biocatalysis. As such, this effort aimed to address these key scientific opportunities to further water purification technologies.

Through the course of this award, the project made substantial progress advancing surface display enzyme technologies. First, the successful engineering of a surface-displayed cutinase biocatalyst enabled the enzymatic treatment of parabens. Achieving this milestone allowed for the exploration of structure-activity relationships and reinforced the modular nature of the surface display enzyme systems. Second, we thoroughly characterized the kinetic properties and transformation pathways of acetaminophen degradation using the surface-displayed laccase biocatalyst. This analysis elucidated potential strategies to mitigate limitations of the surface display enzyme system. Finally, a dual enzyme system was designed for cascade biocatalytic reactions. Combining horseradish peroxidase and glucose oxidase for phenolic contaminant degradation demonstrated the capability for synergistic reactions through simultaneous immobilization of enzymes. These accomplishments underscore the practical versatility of the surface display enzyme system, positioning it as a robust platform technology for application in environmental remediation.

In addition to the results generated regarding surface display enzymes, notable results were produced related to the fabrication of nanostructured, porous substrates that served as supports for the formation of biocatalytic membranes. To achieve the goals of high selectivity, large permeability, and durable mechanical performance, a surface segregation and vapor-induced phase separation process (SVIPS) process was developed to fabricate membrane substrates. Because the resulting materials possessed pore wall chemistries that could be readily modified, in addition to providing a versatile platform for the formation of biocatalytic membranes, these substrates were used as adsorptive membranes for the isolation of dilute solutes from aqueous solutions. For example, we combined the SVIPS methodology with a simple solution-based direct write three-dimensional (3D) printing technique to fabricate adsorptive membranes with precisely controlled patterns and hierarchical structures. Carbon-nanotube-enriched polymer composite inks were formulated to exhibit rheological responses that enable control over the sorbent microstructure through 3D printing. The thermodynamics of the composite inks were engineered such that the SVIPS process initiated as the filaments of polymer solution were being deposited. In this way, as the solution is printed, it nanophase separates to form a porous network within the filaments while the 3D printing allowed highly permeable sorbents to be produced. Through facile post-synthetic reactions, the sorbents were tailored to recover transition metal ions from sub-ppm concentration solutions. This combined technique demonstrates a straightforward method for controlling substrate structure and chemistry across multiple length scales relevant to emerging water treatment and resource recovery process demands.

This project was also instrumental in advancing training and educational programs to prepare the next-generation of scientists and engineers. Four graduate students, including 3 women, were trained through the execution of this award. During this award, the doctoral students were trained on experimental techniques that improved their additive manufacturing, polymer science and engineering, and biocatalysis knowledge to a significant degree. In addition to the training of graduate researchers, five undergraduate researchers and two high school researchers participated in the project. The opportunity to supplement their classroom-based training with meaningful experimentation provided an engaging hands-on component to their training as scientists and engineers. Through these efforts, it is our sincere hope that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2024
Modified by: William A Phillip
